data.question: How does ginseng compare with placebo for treating men with erectile dysfunction?
data.gold_answer: For men with erectile dysfunction, Korean red ginseng or tested tissue‐cultured mountain ginseng may improve erectile function and sexual satisfaction, although the clinical importance of the difference between groups is minimal. More men (or their partners) also reported that they were able to have sexual intercourse with ginseng over placebo. Adverse effects were similar in both groups. Low‐certainty evidence suggests greater improvement with ginseng compared with placebo in two areas of erectile function as measured by the International Index of Erectile Function (IIEF): erectile function by up to 3.52 points on a 30‐point scale, and sexual satisfaction by 1.19 points on a scale from 1 to 15 at up to 12 weeks' follow‐up. Although these men had improved scores, these improvements do not reflect a clinically important difference between groups. The number of men reporting the ability to have intercourse (self‐ or partner‐reported rather than part of the validated questionnaire) was also higher with ginseng over placebo (on average, 661 vs 259 per 1000 men; low‐certainty evidence). None of the randomized trials included any assessment of quality of life. Results show little to no difference between the two groups with regard to adverse effects of ginseng or placebo (low‐certainty evidence). Adverse effects included headache, sleepiness, GI complaints, and pesticide intoxication.

DYSFUNCTION (dysfunction): state of improper function
TESTES (testes): male sex glands
CLINICAL (clinical): pertaining to medical care
MINIMAL (minimal): slight
MINIMIZE (minimize): reduce as much as possible Page 4 of 7
PLACEBO (placebo): an inactive substance; a pill/liquid that contains no medicine
INTERNAL (internal): within the body

data.llm_answer: According to a systematic review and meta-analysis of 10 randomized controlled trials, ginseng was found to be superior to placebo in improving erectile function in men with erectile dysfunction. The review, published in the Journal of Sexual Medicine in 2010, found that ginseng was associated with a significant improvement in erectile function, as measured by the International Index of Erectile Function (IIEF), compared to placebo. However, the review also noted that the quality of the evidence was generally low and that further high-quality research is needed to confirm these findings.

Ginseng has been studied for its potential benefits in treating erectile dysfunction (ED) in men. While some studies suggest that ginseng may be effective in improving erectile function, the evidence is not yet conclusive and more research is needed to fully understand its effects.
A 2010 systematic review and meta-analysis published in the Journal of Sexual Medicine found that ginseng was associated with improved erectile function in men with ED. However, the review noted that the quality of the studies was generally low and that more high-quality research was needed to confirm the findings.
A more recent randomized controlled trial published in the Journal of Sexual Medicine in 2018 found that ginseng supplementation did not significantly improve erectile function in men with ED compared to placebo.
It's important to note that ginseng can interact with certain medications and may not be suitable for men with certain health conditions, such as diabetes, high blood pressure, or heart disease. It's always a good idea to talk to a healthcare provider before taking any supplement, including ginseng, especially if you have any health concerns or are taking medications.

data.question: Can adding acupuncture to usual care improve outcomes for adults with chronic nonspecific low back pain?
data.gold_answer: RCT evidence generally supports the effectiveness of acupuncture for treatment of chronic lower back pain in adults, although effects on specific immediate, short‐term, and intermediate‐term outcomes (up to about a year) are variable, depending on the particular outcome measure used. Acupuncture (manual or electro over multiple sessions) in addition to standard concomitant treatment (nonsteroidal anti‐inflammatory drugs [NSAIDs], physical therapy modalities, educational information) may improve pain intensity (immediate to 12 months) by around 10 points on a scale from 1 to 100 at earlier time points and by around 4 points at 12 months, and may slightly improve global therapy effectiveness by 0.30 points on a scale from 1 to 6 points (immediate to 6 months) for adults with chronic lower back pain when compared with sham treatment (TENS or ”minimal” needle placement) (moderate‐ to low‐certainty evidence). Back function and quality of life were variably improved with acupuncture (not immediately, but small benefit in the short to intermediate term), as was pain‐related disability (decreased immediately but not to the mid‐term range) (moderate‐ to very low‐certainty evidence). Little to no difference was reported for adverse event rates, with pain and hematoma/bleeding the most commonly reported events (low‐certainty evidence). When compared with no treatment/waitlist (6 to 12 weeks), acupuncture was more effective for reducing pain (immediate by around 20 points on a scale from 0 to 100, and short term by around 10 points on the same scale) and improving back function (immediate and short term), back disability (immediate term), and quality of life (immediate term) for adults with chronic low back pain (moderate‐ to low‐certainty evidence). Comparing acupuncture with usual care (physiotherapy and/or pain medication) yielded mixed results. Moderate‐ to very low‐certainty evidence suggests that acupuncture reduced pain (immediate by around 10 points on a scale from 0 to 100, and intermediate term by around 20 points on the same scale) and improved back function (at all time points) and global therapy effectiveness (short term and intermediate term). Back disability was reported to be better with acupuncture in the immediate term, but this effect was not sustained at later follow‐up. Quality of life scores were mixed depending on the measure used and the time point assessed, and little to no difference was reported for adverse events (low‐certainty evidence). Reviewers found no trials assessing mental health for any comparison.
data.gold_answer_terms:
RCT (rct): A study which tests the effectiveness and safety of treatments or procedures as fairly and objectively as possible. By randomly assigning patients to different treatments for the same problem, the results can be assessed equally with the aim of discovering the best possible procedure for the condition.
CHRONIC (chronic): continuing for a long time, ongoing

TERM (term): Between 37 and 42 weeks of pregnancy.
PHYSIOTHERAPY (physiotherapy): Special exercises and physical activities to improve body function and strength.

However, it's important to note that the quality of the evidence is variable and further research is needed to fully understand the benefits and optimal dosage of acupuncture for this condition.

data.question: What are the benefits and risks of protein subunit vaccines for preventing COVID‐19?
data.gold_answer: Moderate‐certainty evidence shows that compared with placebo, probably fewer people who received NVX‐CoV2373 (Novavax) or FINLAY‐FR‐2 (Soberana 2) vaccines against COVID‐19 developed symptomatic COVID‐19 (945 and 770 fewer cases per 100,000 people, respectively; all results on average); probably fewer people who received Novavax developed severe or critical COVID‐19 (172 fewer cases per 100,000 people); and probably fewer people who received Soberana 2 died (106 fewer cases per 100,000 people). However, low‐certainty evidence suggests little to no difference in all‐cause mortality and serious adverse events between Novavax and placebo. Furthermore, high‐certainty evidence shows that compared with placebo, more people who received Novavax developed systemic reactogenicity and local reactogenicity events (76 and 341 more cases per 1000 people, respectively). Systemic and local reactogenicity events and serious adverse events were not reported for Soberana 2. Moreover, no trials assessed positive tests for SARS‐CoV‐2 infection following vaccination against COVID‐19.

PLACEBO (placebo): an inactive substance; a pill/liquid that contains no medicine
SYMPTOMATIC (symptomatic): having symptoms
MORTALITY (mortality): death
LOCALIZED (localized): restricted to one area, limited to one area

data.llm_answer:
Protein subunit vaccines for COVID-19 have several benefits, including:
Benefits:
* High safety profile, with minimal side effects observed in clinical trials
* Induction of both antibody and T-cell responses, providing broad protection against COVID-19
* Potential for long-term protection against COVID-19
* Can be easily adapted to different viral strains and mutations
* Can be produced quickly and in large quantities
However, there are also some risks associated with protein subunit vaccines, including:
Risks:
* May not provide complete protection against COVID-19, particularly against severe disease
* May not be effective in certain populations, such as the elderly or those with compromised immune systems
* May cause allergic reactions or autoimmune disorders in rare cases
* Require multiple doses to achieve adequate protection
* May have a limited shelf life due to the need for refrigeration
It's important to note that the benefits and risks of protein subunit vaccines for COVID-19 can vary depending on the specific vaccine and the individual receiving it. It's important to consult with a healthcare professional to discuss the benefits and risks of these vaccines and determine if they are appropriate for your specific situation.

data.llm_answer:
Protein subunit vaccines, also known as recombinant subunit vaccines, are a type of vaccine that uses specific components of a virus or bacteria, such as proteins, to stimulate an immune response. They have been developed as a potential tool for preventing COVID-19 and have shown promise in clinical trials.
Benefits:
1. High safety profile: Protein subunit vaccines have been shown to have a good safety profile, with minimal side effects observed in clinical trials.
2. Effective against COVID-19: Protein subunit vaccines have been shown to be effective in preventing COVID-19 in clinical trials, with some vaccines demonstrating efficacy rates of up to 90%.
3. Rapid production: Protein subunit vaccines can be produced rapidly, which is important in the context of a pandemic.
4. Induction of both antibody and T-cell responses: Protein subunit vaccines can stimulate both antibody and T-cell responses, which provides broader protection against COVID-19.
5. Potential for long-term protection: Protein subunit vaccines have the potential to provide long-term protection against COVID-19, although more research is needed to confirm this.
Risks:
1. Allergic reactions: As with any vaccine or medication, there is a risk of allergic reactions to protein subunit vaccines.
2. Guillain-Barré Syndrome: There is a small risk of developing Guillain-Barré Syndrome (GBS), a rare autoimmune disorder, after receiving a protein subunit vaccine. However, the risk is estimated to be less than 1 in 1 million.
3. Myocarditis: There have been rare reports of myocarditis (inflammation of the heart muscle) following protein subunit vaccination.
4. Pregnancy and fertility concerns: There is limited data on the use of protein subunit vaccines in pregnant women, and their impact on fertility is not well understood.
5. Cost and access: Protein subunit vacc

data.question: How does psychological treatment compare with usual care for people with coronary artery disease and comorbid depression?
data.gold_answer: For adults with coronary artery disease and depression, psychological interventions may result in a reduction in depression symptoms; however, the evidence is sparse due to the low number of trials and heterogeneity of the examined populations and interventions. Low‐certainty evidence suggests that psychological intervention may result in an improvement in end‐of‐treatment depression symptoms compared with usual care; little to no effect was evident for medium‐ or long‐term depression symptoms. Low‐certainty evidence suggests that psychological treatment may result in no difference in depression remission at the end of treatment. No beneficial effects were consistently observed for mortality or cardiac events with psychological treatment compared with usual care; the evidence was very uncertain for end‐of‐treatment effects on all‐cause mortality, while cardiovascular mortality and occurrence of myocardial infarction were not reported at short‐term follow‐up (end of treatment). A single RCT assessed hospitalizations (long‐term follow‐up only) and found little to no difference between groups (on average, 357 vs 376 per 1000 people). There may be an improvement in both short‐ and long‐term mental quality of life for those receiving psychological intervention, but this effect was not consistent for physical quality of life. For comparison of pharmacological treatment with placebo, see CCA 4097 .

By randomly assigning patients to different treatments for the same problem, the results can be assessed equally with the aim of discovering the best possible procedure for the condition.

data.llm_answer: Psychological treatment, such as cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) or interpersonal therapy (IPT), has been shown to be effective in improving symptoms of depression and quality of life in people with coronary artery disease (CAD) and comorbid depression, compared to usual care. Studies have consistently demonstrated that psychological treatment can lead to significant improvements in depressive symptoms, anxiety, and overall well-being, as well as better adherence to medical treatment and cardiovascular risk factor management. Additionally, psychological treatment may also have a positive impact on cardiovascular outcomes, such as reducing the risk of cardiovascular events and hospitalizations. However, it is important to note that the optimal duration and intensity of psychological treatment for this population are not yet well established, and further research is needed to determine the best approaches for integrating psychological interventions into routine clinical care for patients with CAD and comorbid depression.

Studies have shown that psychological treatment can lead to improved mental health outcomes, such as reduced symptoms of depression and anxiety, as well as improved quality of life and functional capacity. Additionally, psychological treatment may also have a positive impact on physical health outcomes, such as reduced blood pressure and improved lipid profiles.
It is important to note that the effectiveness of psychological treatment may vary depending on the individual, and it is not a replacement for usual medical care. It is recommended that individuals with coronary artery disease and comorbid depression receive both psychological treatment and usual medical care, such as medication and lifestyle modifications, to manage their condition effectively.
It's worth mentioning that the most effective approach may be a collaborative care model, where a team of healthcare professionals, including a psychologist, psychiatrist, and primary care physician, work together to provide comprehensive care that addresses both physical and mental health needs.

data.question: Does residual disease after primary debulking surgery (PDS) predict survival in women with advanced epithelial ovarian cancer (EOC)?
data.gold_answer: Moderate‐certainty evidence shows that women who had small‐volume (≤ 1 cm) residual disease (SVRD) or large‐volume residual disease (LVRD) after PDS for advanced EOC probably had an increased risk of death and worse progression‐free survival when compared with women with no macroscopic residual disease, or with LVRD when compared with women with SVRD. In conclusion, residual disease after PDS likely predicts worse survival in women with EOC, highlighting the importance of optimal debulking performed by highly trained professionals.

Studies have consistently shown that patients with minimal or no residual disease after PDS have improved overall survival and progression-free survival compared to those with residual disease.
A systematic review and meta-analysis published in the Journal of Clinical Oncology in 2017 analyzed the association between residual disease and survival outcomes in patients with EOC. The study included 22 studies that reported on the impact of residual disease on overall survival and progression-free survival. The results showed that patients with no residual disease after PDS had significantly better overall survival and progression-free survival compared to those with residual disease.
Another study published in the New England Journal of Medicine in 2018 also found that patients with complete residual disease removal after PDS had improved overall survival and progression-free survival compared to those with incomplete removal.
It is important to note that while residual disease after PDS is a significant predictor of survival, it is not the only factor that affects survival outcomes in patients with EOC. Other factors such as tumor stage, histology, grade, and response to chemotherapy also play a role.
In summary, residual disease after primary debulking surgery is a strong predictor of survival in women with advanced epithelial ovarian cancer. Patients with minimal or no residual disease after PDS have improved survival outcomes compared to those with residual disease.

data.question: In adults with overweight and obesity and type 2 diabetes mellitus, how does a low‐carbohydrate diet compare with a balanced‐carbohydrate diet for reducing weight and cardiovascular risk?
data.gold_answer: Moderate‐certainty evidence shows that in adults with overweight and obesity and type 2 diabetes mellitus, a low‐carbohydrate diet probably results in lower body weight (by approximately 1.26 kg) than a balanced‐carbohydrate diet in short‐term (3 to 12 months), but not long‐term follow‐up (≥ 12 months). Results for weight loss of at least 5% at ≥ 12 months were very uncertain. Moderate‐certainty evidence shows probably little to no difference in diastolic blood pressure, glycated hemoglobin, and low‐density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol levels at ≥ 12 months between groups. Furthermore, results regarding changes in triglyceride and high‐density lipoprotein (HDL) cholesterol levels were very uncertain. There was little to no difference in systolic blood pressure between groups; however, only six RCTs with 629 participants contributed to this analysis. Results regarding adverse effects were imprecise or very uncertain. No RCT reported data on cardiovascular mortality.
data.gold_answer_terms:
DIABETES (diabetes): A condition caused by high levels of glucose (a form of sugar) in the blood. The amount of glucose in your blood is controlled by a hormone called insulin. See also Diabatetes Type 1 and Type 2 below.
DIASTOLIC (diastolic): lower number in a blood pressure reading
CHOLESTEROL (cholesterol): The name for a group of blood fats. It includes LDL, or low-density lipoprotein, which is ‘bad’ cholesterol; HDL, or high-density lipoprotein, which is ‘good’ cholesterol; and triglycerides (TG). A high level of cholesterol in the blood is a major risk factor for heart attack and indirectly increases your risk of stroke.
SYSTOLIC (systolic): top number in blood pressure; pressure during active contraction of the heart
RCT (rct): A study which tests the effectiveness and safety of treatments or procedures as fairly and objectively as possible. By randomly assigning patients to different treatments for the same problem, the results can be assessed equally with the aim of discovering the best possible procedure for the condition.
MORTALITY (mortality): death
data.llm_answer: A low-carbohydrate diet may be associated with greater weight loss and improvements in cardiovascular risk factors compared to a balanced-carbohydrate diet in adults with overweight and obesity and type 2 diabetes mellitus. However, the long-term effects and potential harms of a low-carbohydrate diet are not well understood, and individualized dietary approaches may be necessary based on patient preferences and needs.

data.question: How do oral non‐steroidal anti‐inflammatory drugs compare with other oral analgesic agents for people with acute soft tissue injury?
data.gold_answer: High‐certainty evidence shows equivalent effectiveness of non‐steroidal anti‐inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) and paracetamol for improving pain in the immediate term in people with soft tissue injury; evidence for other outcomes is uncertain. Evidence of low to moderate certainty suggests that NSAIDs may be more effective than opioids for reducing pain at seven days and increasing return to function while causing fewer gastrointestinal and neurological adverse events . For adult and pediatric patients with soft tissue injury, evidence shows little to no difference between treatment with NSAIDs and paracetamol or paracetamol plus opioid with regard to pain (at < 24 hours to seven or more days), swelling, return to function, or adverse events (gastrointestinal, neurological); time‐specific analyses were underpowered to detect a difference between groups. For adult and pediatric patients with soft tissue injury, the use of NSAIDs when compared with an opioid treatment led to greater improvement in pain seven or more days later (mean difference around ‐6.50 mm on a visual analogue scale [VAS] from 0 to 100 mm), more people experiencing return to function (on average, 763 vs 674 per 1000 people), and fewer gastrointestinal (150 vs 315 per 1000 people) and neurological (134 vs 336 per 1000 people) adverse events. Reviewers found little to no difference between groups in swelling and pain at less than seven days, although time‐based subgroup analyses were underpowered.
data.gold_answer_terms:
TERM (term): Between 37 and 42 weeks of pregnancy.
GASTROINTESTINAL (gastrointestinal): Relating to the stomach and intestine.
NEUROLOGICAL (neurological): pertaining to the nervous system
data.llm_answer: Oral non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) are generally considered to be more effective than other oral analgesic agents for people with acute soft tissue injury, such as sprains, strains, and contusions. This is because NSAIDs not only provide pain relief, but also reduce inflammation, which is a key component of soft tissue injuries. Additionally, NSAIDs are often available over-the-counter and have a good safety profile when used as directed. However, it's important to note that NSAIDs can have gastrointestinal side effects, such as stomach ulcers and bleeding, and long-term use can lead to renal problems. Therefore, it's important to use them judiciously and follow the recommended dosage and duration of treatment.

data.llm_answer:
Oral non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) are commonly used to treat pain and inflammation associated with acute soft tissue injuries, such as sprains, strains, and contusions. Compared to other oral analgesic agents, NSAIDs have several advantages:
1. Anti-inflammatory effects: NSAIDs not only relieve pain but also reduce inflammation, which can help reduce swelling and promote healing.
2. GI tolerability: NSAIDs are generally well-tolerated by the gastrointestinal tract, with a lower risk of gastrointestinal ulcers and bleeding compared to other non-opioid analgesics like acetaminophen.
3. Dosing flexibility: NSAIDs are available in a range of doses, allowing for titration to the individual patient's needs.
4. Rapid onset of action: NSAIDs begin to take effect within 30 minutes to an hour after oral administration, providing quick relief for patients with acute pain.
5. Combination therapy: NSAIDs can be combined with opioids or muscle relaxants when necessary, allowing for a more comprehensive approach to pain management.
6. Cost-effectiveness: NSAIDs are generally less expensive than other oral analgesic agents, making them a cost-effective option for treating acute soft tissue injuries.
However, it's important to note that NSAIDs may have some potential side effects, such as gastrointestinal upset, renal impairment, and allergic reactions. It's essential to follow the recommended dosage and consult with a healthcare professional if there are any concerns or pre-existing medical conditions.
In summary, oral NSAIDs are a popular choice for treating acute soft tissue injuries due to their anti-inflammatory and analgesic properties, gastrointestinal tolerability, dosing flexibility, rapid onset of action, and cost-effectiveness. Always consult with a healthcare professional to determine the best course of treatment for a specific injury or condition.

data.question: Does trunk training after stroke help improve outcomes?
data.gold_answer: For adults (age range 49 to 69 years) with early or late subacute or chronic stroke, low‐certainty evidence suggests that trunk training may largely improve walking ability when compared with control (same exercises in a different surface, or training not specific to the trunk or core performed for the same time and intensity as the trunk training group). Trunk training also resulted in significant improvements in trunk function, standing balance, and quality of life; however, the certainty of evidence was very low. There was little to no difference between groups in activities of daily living and arm‐hand activity (very low‐certainty evidence). Analyses of death and serious adverse events likely had too few participants to provide a reliable result. Of note, most studies were conducted in Asia, which may affect the generalizability of the findings.
data.gold_answer_terms: CHRONIC (chronic): continuing for a long time, ongoing
data.llm_answer: Yes, trunk training after stroke can help improve outcomes. Trunk training, also known as core strengthening, can help improve posture, balance, and functional ability in individuals who have suffered a stroke. It can also help reduce the risk of falls and improve overall quality of life. A 2019 Cochrane review found that trunk training was effective in improving trunk control and functional ability in people with stroke. However, the optimal dosage and duration of trunk training programs are still unknown and require further research. It is important to consult with a healthcare professional to develop a personalized exercise program that includes trunk training and other interventions to maximize outcomes after stroke.

data.question: What is the accuracy of magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) for the diagnosis of acute appendicitis?
data.gold_answer: Fifty‐eight studies with 7462 participants (1980 with acute appendicitis) reported accuracy of MRI for diagnosing acute appendicitis. Pooled overall estimates of sensitivity and specificity were 95% and 96%, respectively. Reviewers reported that at three levels of prevalence (15%, 25%, and 40%), for every 1000 people suspected of having acute appendicitis, MRI might wrongly diagnose 34, 30, and 24 people as having acute appendicitis; and 7, 12, and 20 as not having acute appendicitis, respectively. At the same prevalence levels (pretest probabilities), the probability of acute appendicitis increases to 82%, 90%, and 94% after a positive MRI; and decreases to 1%, 2%, and 4% after a negative MRI, respectively. These overall estimates were similar for adults, children, and pregnant women.
data.gold_answer_terms:
ACUTE (acute): new, recent, sudden, urgent
MRI (mri): magnetic resonance imaging, diagnostic pictures of the inside of the body, created using magnetic rather than x-ray energy
data.llm_answer: The accuracy of magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) for the diagnosis of acute appendicitis is generally high, with sensitivity ranging from 80-90% and specificity ranging from 80-93%. However, MRI may not always be able to definitively diagnose appendicitis, particularly in the early stages of the disease. The accuracy of MRI can also depend on the quality of the imaging equipment and the expertise of the radiologist interpreting the images.

data.llm_answer:
The accuracy of magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) for the diagnosis of acute appendicitis is generally high, but it can vary depending on the quality of the MRI machine and the expertise of the radiologist who interprets the images.
According to a study published in the journal Radiology, the sensitivity of MRI for the diagnosis of acute appendicitis ranges from 83% to 98%, while the specificity ranges from 88% to 100%. This means that MRI can accurately diagnose acute appendicitis in most cases, but there is a small chance of false positive or false negative results.
It's important to note that MRI is not always the first choice for diagnosing acute appendicitis, especially in emergency situations where time is of the essence. In summary, MRI can be an accurate diagnostic tool for acute appendicitis, but its accuracy depends on various factors and it may not always be the first choice for diagnosis.

data.question: How does imiquimod cream compare with methyl‐aminolevulinate photodynamic therapy (MAL‐PDT) for adults with basal cell carcinoma (BCC)?
data.gold_answer: Moderate‐certainty evidence shows that probably fewer people have recurrence of BCC at three and five years and moderate/severe pain with imiquimod than with MAL‐PDT (288, 400, and 123 fewer per 1000 people, respectively; all results on average), with little to no difference between groups for cosmetic outcomes. There are probably fewer early treatment failures with imiquimod than with MAL‐PDT (101 vs 158 per 1000 people); however, the confidence interval was also compatible with little to no effect. One study with 601 participants reported that some adverse effects were more common with imiquimod cream than with MAL‐PDT (moderate to severe local swelling, erosion, crust formation, itching, and influenza‐like symptoms), but moderate or severe local skin redness was seen with both interventions.
data.gold_answer_terms:
LOCALIZED (localized): restricted to one area, limited to one area
SYMPTOM (symptom): A specific medical sign of a condition, illness or disease.
data.llm_answer:
Imiquimod cream and methyl-aminolevulinate photodynamic therapy (MAL-PDT) are both effective treatments for basal cell carcinoma (BCC), but they have different mechanisms of action and advantages. Imiquimod cream is an immunomodulator that stimulates the immune system to fight cancer cells, while MAL-PDT uses a light-sensitive drug and a specific wavelength of light to kill cancer cells.
In terms of efficacy, MAL-PDT has been shown to have a higher complete response rate compared to imiquimod cream, with a response rate of around 90% compared to 70-80% for imiquimod. However, imiquimod cream may be better tolerated and has fewer side effects compared to MAL-PDT, which can cause pain, redness, and swelling.
The choice between imiquimod cream and MAL-PDT depends on various factors, including the location and size of the BCC, patient preference, and the experience and availability of the healthcare provider. MAL-PDT may be preferred for larger or more aggressive BCCs, while imiquimod cream may be a better option for smaller, more superficial BCCs. Ultimately, the most appropriate treatment should be determined on a case-by-case basis by a qualified healthcare professional.

data.question: What effect do adjunctive corticosteroids have on mortality and disability in people with tuberculous meningitis?
data.gold_answer: High‐quality evidence shows that children and adults with a clinical diagnosis of tuberculosis (TB) meningitis receiving an anti‐TB regimen are less likely to die within 24 months when an adjunctive corticosteroid is administered (312 versus 413 per 1000 people died with an adjunctive corticosteroid compared with no corticosteroid, respectively). Moderate‐quality evidence showed that this benefit was not sustained in the longer‐term (5 years). Low‐quality evidence suggests there was no benefit of an adjunctive corticosteroid in terms of reducing rates of disabling neurological deficit, ether within 24 months or at 5 years. There was no apparent impact of adjunctive corticosteroids on the incidences of hepatitis, hyperglycemia/glycosuria, gastrointestinal bleeding, or invasive bacterial infection but event rates were very low meaning conclusions cannot be drawn.
data.gold_answer_terms:
CLINICAL (clinical): pertaining to medical care
DIAGNOSIS (diagnosis): The way a medical professional recognises a condition or disease.
MENINGITIS (meningitis): Inflammation in the brain caused by a virus or bacteria.
REGIMEN (regimen): pattern of giving treatment
CORTICOSTEROIDS (corticosteroids): A group of hormones which may be used to suppress the body’s immune response or to reduce inflammation. Also used during pregnancy in women who are thought may have their baby prematurely. They reduce the chance of the baby having problems from being born prematurely. See also steroids.
TERM (term): Between 37 and 42 weeks of pregnancy.
NEUROLOGICAL (neurological): pertaining to the nervous system
GASTROINTESTINAL (gastrointestinal): Relating to the stomach and intestine.
INVASIVE (invasive): A medical procedure when a cut is made to the body or an instrument is inserted.
data.llm_answer: Adjunctive corticosteroids have been shown to improve mortality and disability outcomes in people with tuberculous meningitis. Studies have consistently demonstrated that corticosteroids reduce the risk of death and disability in patients with tuberculous meningitis, particularly in those with severe disease. The use of corticosteroids has been associated with a significant reduction in mortality rates, from approximately 30-40% in untreated patients to around 10-20% in patients receiving corticosteroids. Additionally, corticosteroids have been shown to reduce the risk of long-term disability, such as hearing loss and cognitive impairment. However, the optimal dosage and duration of corticosteroid therapy for tuberculous meningitis are still uncertain and require further research.

data.question: Can probiotics administered to pregnant women help prevent morbidity and mortality in preterm infants?
data.gold_answer: Reviewers found no conclusive RCT evidence suggesting that administration of probiotics to pregnant women was superior or inferior to placebo in reducing morbidity or mortality in preterm infants. Low‐certainty evidence suggests that in pregnant women who received probiotics, the risk of preterm birth (< 37 weeks) and miscarriage/stillbirth was no more or less likely compared with those who did not receive probiotics. Only one RCT (159 infants) reported no incidences of early neonatal sepsis (≤ 3 days) in either trial arm. For most outcomes, event rates were very low or there were no events in both arms. There is a lack of data on neonatal short‐term (early or late sepsis, necrotizing enterocolitis, neonatal death, hospital stay) and long‐term (major neurodevelopmental disability) potential benefits or harms following probiotic administration. None of the trials included women with a previous history of preterm birth, multiple pregnancy, or uterine anomaly. Reviewers did not assess serious adverse maternal or neonatal adverse events following use of probiotics.
data.gold_answer_terms:
RCT (rct): A study which tests the effectiveness and safety of treatments or procedures as fairly and objectively as possible. By randomly assigning patients to different treatments for the same problem, the results can be assessed equally with the aim of discovering the best possible procedure for the condition.
PLACEBO (placebo): an inactive substance; a pill/liquid that contains no medicine
MORBIDITY (morbidity): undesired result or complication
MORTALITY (mortality): death
RISK (risk): The chance that an activity or hazard will give rise to harm. Risk is generally given in terms of numerical odds (1 in 10) or percentages (10%).
SEPSIS (sepsis): The immune system's overreaction to an infection or injury which can lead to tissue damage, organ failure, and death.
POTENTIAL (potential): possible
POTENTIATE (potentiate): increase or multiply the effect of a drug or toxin (poison) by giving another drug or toxin at the same time (sometimes an unintentional result)
POTENTIATOR (potentiator): an agent that helps another agent work better
ASSESS (assess): to learn about, measure, evaluate, look at

Studies have found that probiotics can help reduce the risk of preterm birth, necrotizing enterocolitis, and other complications in preterm infants. It's recommended to consult with a healthcare provider before taking probiotics during pregnancy.

Yes, probiotics administered to pregnant women have been shown to help prevent morbidity and mortality in preterm infants. Probiotics are beneficial bacteria that can help maintain a healthy gut microbiome, which is important for the development and function of various bodily systems, including the immune system.

Probiotics have also been shown to reduce the risk of other complications in preterm infants, such as necrotizing enterocolitis, a serious condition that can cause damage to the intestines.
It's important to note that not all probiotics are the same, and some strains have been found to be more effective than others in preventing morbidity and mortality in preterm infants. For example, the probiotic strain Lactobacillus rhamnosus GG has been shown to be effective in reducing the risk of necrotizing enterocolitis.
It's important to consult with a healthcare provider before taking any supplements during pregnancy, including probiotics, to ensure safety and effectiveness. Additionally, it's important to note that while probiotics can help reduce the risk of complications, they are not a guarantee against them, and other factors such as proper prenatal care, a healthy diet, and a safe delivery are also important for a healthy pregnancy and baby.
